case_name: State v. Chairman of the Malegaon Powerloom Sadi Manufacturers Cooperative Association Ltd.

facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 168 of 1961 in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 168 of 1961. Appeal

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 3, 1951, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 99 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 3, 1951, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 99 of 1961. Shaukat Husain and P. C. Agarwala, for the Appellant. K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India, D. R. Prem and R. N. Sachthey, for the respondent. 1963. February 7. The judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL,J.-This appeal, by special leave, is against the order of the High Court of Bombay allowing the State appeal and companyvicting the appellant of the offence under s. 5 of the Imports and Exports  Control  Act, 1947, hereinafter called the Act, for having companytravened the Imports  Control  Order, 1955, hereinafter called the Order, and sentencing him to three months rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 2,000/- .

facts.text: The judgment was delivered on February 7, 1963 by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. February 7. The judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL,J.-This appeal, by special leave, is against the order of the High Court of Bombay allowing the State appeal and companyvicting the appellant of the offence under s. 5 of the Imports and Exports  Control  Act, 1947, hereinafter called the Act, for having companytravened the Imports  Control  Order, 1955, hereinafter called the Order, and sentencing him to three months rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 2,000/- . The appellant was the Chairman of the Malegaon Powerloom Sadi Manufacturers Cooperative Association Ltd., hereinafter called the Association.

facts.text: Bombay High Court convicted the appellant under section 5 of the Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947 for contravening the Imports Control Order, 1955 and sentenced him to three months rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 2,000.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, is against the order of the High Court of Bombay allowing the State appeal and companyvicting the appellant of the offence under s. 5 of the Imports and Exports  Control  Act, 1947, hereinafter called the Act, for having companytravened the Imports  Control  Order, 1955, hereinafter called the Order, and sentencing him to three months rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 2,000/- . The appellant was the Chairman of the Malegaon Powerloom Sadi Manufacturers Cooperative Association Ltd., hereinafter called the Association. There were six other members of the Association. All the members were powerloom weavers.

facts.text: Appellant was the Chairman of the Malegaon Powerloom Sadi Manufacturers Cooperative Association Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was the Chairman of the Malegaon Powerloom Sadi Manufacturers Cooperative Association Ltd., hereinafter called the Association. There were six other members of the Association. All the members were powerloom weavers. The appellant, as Chairman of the Association, applied for and obtained the licence dated January 2, 1956, for the import of certain quantity of art silk yarn by the Association.

facts.text: Association had six other members, all powerloom weavers.

anchor.surface_text: There were six other members of the Association. All the members were powerloom weavers. The appellant, as Chairman of the Association, applied for and obtained the licence dated January 2, 1956, for the import of certain quantity of art silk yarn by the Association. The licence was issued subject to the companydition that the good, would be utilised only for companysumption as raw material or accessories in the licence- holders factory and that numberportion thereof would be sold to any party.

facts.text: Appellant, as Chairman, applied for and obtained import licence dated January 2, 1956 for certain quantity of art silk yarn by the Association.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, as Chairman of the Association, applied for and obtained the licence dated January 2, 1956, for the import of certain quantity of art silk yarn by the Association. The licence was issued subject to the companydition that the good, would be utilised only for companysumption as raw material or accessories in the licence- holders factory and that numberportion thereof would be sold to any party. The Association companyld number arrange for the necessary finances and therefore had the goods imported through Warden Co., who financed the transaction.

facts.text: Licence issued subject to condition that goods would be utilised only for consumption as raw material or accessories in the licence-holder's factory and no portion sold to any party.

anchor.surface_text: The licence was issued subject to the companydition that the good, would be utilised only for companysumption as raw material or accessories in the licence- holders factory and that numberportion thereof would be sold to any party. The Association companyld number arrange for the necessary finances and therefore had the goods imported through Warden Co., who financed the transaction. Part of the goods received was utilised in accordance with the companydition of the licence, the rest was however sold by the said Warden Co., as a result of the companyrespondence ending by a letter dated November 13, 1956, from the appellant as Chairman of the Association to Warden Co.

facts.text: Association could not arrange finances and had goods imported through Warden Co., who financed the transaction.

anchor.surface_text: The Association companyld number arrange for the necessary finances and therefore had the goods imported through Warden Co., who financed the transaction. Part of the goods received was utilised in accordance with the companydition of the licence, the rest was however sold by the said Warden Co., as a result of the companyrespondence ending by a letter dated November 13, 1956, from the appellant as Chairman of the Association to Warden Co. The relevant portion of this letter is In this companynection we have to inform you that as the price of Art silk yarn has fallen greatly it is number possible for our Association to take delivery of the balance goods.

facts.text: Part of the goods received was utilised in accordance with the condition of the licence, the rest was sold by Warden Co.

anchor.surface_text: Part of the goods received was utilised in accordance with the companydition of the licence, the rest was however sold by the said Warden Co., as a result of the companyrespondence ending by a letter dated November 13, 1956, from the appellant as Chairman of the Association to Warden Co. The relevant portion of this letter is In this companynection we have to inform you that as the price of Art silk yarn has fallen greatly it is number possible for our Association to take delivery of the balance goods. As such, you are therefore requested to dispose of the balance goods lying with you in such manner that our Association suffers numberloss whatsoever, but gets a net profit of at least 4 on these goods.

facts.text: Appellant wrote letter dated November 13, 1956 to Warden Co. requesting disposal of balance goods for no loss but net profit of at least 4%.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant portion of this letter is In this companynection we have to inform you that as the price of Art silk yarn has fallen greatly it is number possible for our Association to take delivery of the balance goods. As such, you are therefore requested to dispose of the balance goods lying with you in such manner that our Association suffers numberloss whatsoever, but gets a net profit of at least 4 on these goods. After the disposal of the goods Warden Co, did pay to the Association a sum of Rs. 5,040/- by way of profits of the Association.

facts.text: After disposal of goods, Warden Co. paid Rs. 5,040/- to the Association by way of profits.

anchor.surface_text: After the disposal of the goods Warden Co, did pay to the Association a sum of Rs. 5,040/- by way of profits of the Association. The appellant and the other members of the Association were prosecuted for companymitting the offence under s. 5 of the Act. They were acquitted by the trial Court. The State appealed against the acquittal of the appellant alone.

facts.text: Appellant and other members of Association prosecuted for offence under s.5 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and the other members of the Association were prosecuted for companymitting the offence under s. 5 of the Act. They were acquitted by the trial Court. The State appealed against the acquittal of the appellant alone. The appeal was allowed, with the result that the appellant was companyvicted of the offence under s. 5 of the Act.

facts.text: All accused acquitted by the trial Court.

anchor.surface_text: They were acquitted by the trial Court. The State appealed against the acquittal of the appellant alone. The appeal was allowed, with the result that the appellant was companyvicted of the offence under s. 5 of the Act. He has companye up in appeal.

facts.text: State appealed against acquittal of appellant alone to Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State appealed against the acquittal of the appellant alone. The appeal was allowed, with the result that the appellant was companyvicted of the offence under s. 5 of the Act. He has companye up in appeal. The various companytentions raised for the appellant are  i  The Act was intended for the purpose of prohibiting or companytrolling imports and exports which, according to s. 2 thereof, meant respectively bringing goods into and taking out of India by sea, land or air, and therefore any provision in the Order providing for the issue of a licence to import goods subject to the companydition that the goods companyered by the licence be number disposed of except in the manner prescribed by the licensing authority companyld number be validly made in the exercise of the powers companyferred on the Central Government under s. 3 of the Act, as such a companydition deals with the companyduct of the licensee subsequent to the import of the goods.

facts.text: High Court allowed the State appeal and convicted the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was allowed, with the result that the appellant was companyvicted of the offence under s. 5 of the Act. He has companye up in appeal.

facts.text: Appellant claims possession of goods had not passed to Association.

anchor.surface_text: v  The possession of the goods had number passed to the Association and therefore the Association companyld number be guilty of the offence.

facts.text: Appellant claims no mens rea to commit the offence.

anchor.surface_text: vi  The appellant has numbermens rea to companymit the offence and therefore companyld number be guilty of the offence.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds appellant intentionally aided the Association in committing the offence, thus abetted it.

anchor.surface_text: Re the sixth point that the appellant had numberintention to companymit the offence, the finding of the High Court is against the appellant. The High Court rightly held him guilty of the offence under S. 5 of the Act on a finding that he intentionally aided the Association, the licensee, in companymitting the offence under s. 5 of the Act, and thus abetted the companytravention of the offence by the Association.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that contravention of licence condition amounts to contravention of the Order and punishable under s.5 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The third companytention too has numberforce. Sub-cl.  4  of cl. 5 provides that the licensee shall companyply with all companyditions imposed or deemed to be imposed under that clause. The companytravention of any companydition of a licence thus amounts to the Contravention of the provisions of sub-cl.  4  of cl. 5 of the Order and companysequently to the companytravention of the Order made under the Act.

facts.text: Association was the licensee.

anchor.surface_text: iv  The Association was the licensee and therefore any companytravention of the companydition of the licence would be companymitted by the Association and number by its Chairman and companysequently it would be the Association which should have been tried for the alleged offence under s. 5 of the Act and number the Chairman.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses appeal and upholds conviction.

anchor.surface_text: The case appears to be a deliberate case of securing import licence with a view to mis-apply the goods imported.

anchor.surface_text: The section was amended in 1960 and as a result of the amendment the contravening of any condition of the licence granted under the order, was also made punishable. The amended provision, however, is not applicable to the present case.

concepts.interpretation: Pre-amendment s.5 applicable; explicitly made licence condition contravention punishable post-1960 but not here.

issues.text: Whether the Act was intended only for prohibiting or controlling imports and exports at the point of entry into India such that a condition in the licence restricting post-import disposal of goods could not be validly made under s. 3 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The Act was intended for the purpose of prohibiting or controlling imports and exports which, according to s. 2 thereof, meant respectively bringing goods into and taking out of India by sea, land or air, and therefore any provision in the Order providing for the issue of a licence to import goods subject to the condition that the goods covered by the licence be not disposed of except in the manner prescribed by the licensing authority could not be validly made in the exercise of the powers conferred on the Central Government under s. 3 of the Act, as such a condition deals with the conduct of the licensee subsequent to the import of the goods.

issues.text: Whether the Order provides for the imposition of the condition in the licence that the licensee is not to sell the imported goods

anchor.surface_text: ii the Order does not provide for the imposition of the condition in the licence that the licensee is not to sell the imported goods.

issues.text: Whether the contravention of any condition of the licence amounts to a contravention of the provisions of the Act or an Order made thereunder and is punishable under s. 5 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: iii The contravention of any condition of the licence does not amount to a contravention of the provisions of the Act or an Order made thereunder and therefore is not punishable under s. 5 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the contravention of the condition of the licence would be committed only by the Association as licensee and not by its Chairman, such that only the Association should be tried under s. 5 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: iv The Association was the licensee and therefore any contravention of the condition of the licence would be committed by the Association and not by its Chairman and consequently it would be the Association which should have been tried for the alleged offence under s. 5 of the Act and not the Chairman.

issues.text: Whether the Association could be guilty of the offence given that possession of the goods had not passed to it

anchor.surface_text: v The possession of the goods had not passed to the Association and therefore the Association could not be guilty of the offence.

issues.text: Whether the appellant had mens rea to commit the offence

anchor.surface_text: vi The appellant has no mens rea to commit the offence and therefore could not be guilty of the offence.

issues.text: Whether the sentence imposed is severe

anchor.surface_text: vii Lastly, the sentence is severe.

issues.text: Whether the appellant abetted the contravention of the Order by the Association

anchor.surface_text: the High Court rightly held him guilty of the offence under S. 5 of the Act on a finding that he intentionally aided the Association, the licensee, in committing the offence under s. 5 of the Act, and thus abetted the contravention of the offence by the Association.

arguments.claim: The Act was intended for the purpose of prohibiting or controlling imports and exports which meant bringing goods into India, so condition restricting post-import disposal cannot be validly made under s.3 as it deals with conduct subsequent to import.

anchor.surface_text: i  The Act was intended for the purpose of prohibiting or controlling imports and exports which, according to s. 2 thereof, meant respectively bringing goods into and taking out of India by sea, land or air, and therefore any provision in the Order providing for the issue of a licence to import goods subject to the condition that the goods covered by the licence be not disposed of except in the manner prescribed by the licensing authority could not be validly made in the exercise of the powers conferred on the Central Government under s. 3 of the Act, as such a condition deals with the conduct of the licensee subsequent to the import of the goods.

arguments.court_reasoning: Power under s.3 extends to controlling subsequent disposal for effective import control; policy requires control over utilisation; distinguishes Balsara as limited to legislative competence context.

arguments.claim: The Order does not provide for the imposition of the condition in the licence that the licensee is not to sell the imported goods.

anchor.surface_text: ii  the Order does not provide for the imposition of the condition in the licence that the licensee is not to sell the imported goods.

anchor.surface_text: iii  The contravention of any condition of the licence does not amount to a contravention of the provisions of the Act or an Order made thereunder and therefore is not punishable under s. 5 of the Act.

arguments.claim: The Association was the licensee so contravention committed by Association not Chairman; Association should have been tried not Chairman.

arguments.court_reasoning: Actual possession unnecessary for contravention; Warden Co.'s possession as agent attributed to Association.

anchor.surface_text: vii  Lastly, the sentence is severe.

arguments.court_reasoning: Deliberate misuse from beginning; sentence not severe given circumstances and profit made.

arguments.claim: Power under s.3 extends to controlling disposal after import as necessary for effective control.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear therefore that the power conferred under s. 3 of the Act is not restricted merely to prohibiting or restricting imports at the point of entry but extends also to controlling the subsequent disposal of the goods imported.

arguments.claim: Balsara case inapplicable as it concerned legislative competence under Govt of India Act not interpretation of import/export in this Act.

anchor.surface_text: That case dealt with a different matter. It related to the powers under the Bombay Prohibition Act, 1949... This observation cannot be applicable to the interpretation of the content of the words import and export in the Act in the present case.

arguments.claim: Glass Chatons and Daya cases support that s.3 power includes post-import distribution control.

anchor.surface_text: In Glass Chatons Importers Users Association v. Union of India, it was contended that s. 3... the Court held that provision good. In Daya v. Joint Chief Controller... could be made in the exercise of the power conferred on the Central Government under s. 3 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Licensing authority competent under cl.5(2) to impose condition not to sell unlike narrower 1948 order in East India Commercial Co.

anchor.surface_text: In that case, a condition was imposed... The language of sub-cl. (2) of cl. 5 of that Order is wide and permits the imposition of a condition which was outside sub- cl. v of cl. a of the order of 1948.

arguments.claim: Contravention of licence condition contravenes sub-cl.(4) of cl.5 hence the Order and punishable under s.5; prior cases inapplicable lacking sub-cl.(4).

anchor.surface_text: Sub-cl. (4) of cl. 5 provides that the licensee shall comply with all conditions imposed or deemed to be imposed under that clause. The contravention of any condition of a licence thus amounts to the Contravention of the provisions of sub-cl. (4) of cl. 5 of the Order and consequently to the contravention of the Order made under the Act.

arguments.claim: Chairman abetted Association's contravention by intentionally aiding via letter to Warden Co. to dispose for profit.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly held him guilty of the offence under S. 5 of the Act on a finding that he intentionally aided the Association, the licensee, in committing the offence under s. 5 of the Act, and thus abetted the contravention of the offence by the Association.

arguments.claim: Warden Co. possession is Association's possession as agent.

anchor.surface_text: Further, the possession of Warden Co., would be possession of the Association, as the former was its agent to import the goods.

arguments.claim: Case is deliberate securing of licence to misapply imported goods.

anchor.surface_text: The case appears to be a deliberate case of securing import licence with a view to mis-apply the goods imported.

holdings.text: The provision in cl. 5 of the Order empowering the licensing authority to attach a condition to the effect that the goods covered by the licence shall not be disposed of except in the manner prescribed by the licensing authority is a valid provision which comes within the powers conferred by s. 3 of the Act on the Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the provision in cl. 5 of the Order empowering the licensing authority to attach a condition to the effect that the goods covered by the licence shall not be disposed of, except in the manner

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power under s.3 not limited to entry point but extends to post-import disposal for effective control; distinguishes Balsara; follows Glass Chatons and Daya precedents.

holdings.text: The licensing authority is competent under the Order to impose the condition that the imported goods be not sold to any person and thus to affect the ordinary rights of the importer.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide language in sub-cl.(2) of cl.5 permits such conditions, unlike narrower 1948 order; sub-cl.(4) requires compliance; distinguishes East India Commercial Co.

holdings.text: The contravention of any condition of a licence thus amounts to the Contravention of the provisions of sub-cl. (4) of cl. 5 of the Order and consequently to the contravention of the Order made under the Act. It follows that if the Association, the licensee, does not comply with the conditions of the licence about use of the goods to be imported, it contravenes the Order made under the Act and makes itself liable to punishment under s. 5 of the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-cl.(4) mandates compliance with all conditions; breach contravenes Order punishable under s.5; prior cases inapplicable without equivalent provision.

holdings.text: It is the Association, the licensee, which alone could contravene the condition of the licence and thus contravene the Order.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Association as licensee directly contravenes, but Chairman separately liable for abetment.

holdings.text: For contravening the condition of the licence, actual possession of the imported goods is not necessary. Further, the possession of Warden Co., would be possession of the Association, as the former was its agent to import the goods.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Actual possession unnecessary; agent's possession attributed to principal/licensee.

holdings.text: The High Court rightly held him guilty of the offence under S. 5 of the Act on a finding that he intentionally aided the Association, the licensee, in committing the offence under s. 5 of the Act, and thus abetted the contravention of the offence by the Association.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant intentionally aided via letter authorizing sale for profit, constituting abetment under s.5.

holdings.text: We do not consider that the sentence is severe in the circumstances of the case which indicate that from the very beginning the appellant, as Chairman of the Association, knew that the Association would not be able to utilise all the yarn to be imported under the licence applied for.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Deliberate scheme to misuse licence; profit made; sentence proportionate.

holdings.text: The appellant intentionally aided the Association in disposing of the goods through Warden Co., and therefore abetted the contravention of the condition of the licence to the effect that the goods imported would be utilised by the licensee alone and would not be sold to any other party.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Letter requesting disposal for profit shows intentional aid in contravention.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal against conviction dismissed; High Court order upheld confirming conviction under s. 5 of the Act and sentence of three months' rigorous imprisonment and fine of Rs. 2,000; no interference with sentence

a10 cites precedents supporting s.3 power for post-import control, addressing i1's claim limiting Act to entry point
